narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled 'NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants' expects to generate demographic, clinical, and MRI-based imaging data including structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS, along with derived imaging measures/features. The dataset will comprise participant-level clinical/demographic tables for 220 participants (110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls) and multi-modal MRI imaging data. The total volume of the dataset will depend on the imaging protocols used and the derivatives retained, with the imaging data expected to be the largest component.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected demographic, clinical, and MRI-based imaging data, including structural MRI, fMRI, 1H fMRS, and derived measures, will be preserved and shared. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and advancement of research in the field by providing a comprehensive dataset that can be used by other researchers to explore new hypotheses, validate findings, and develop new methodologies.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible:
- Data dictionaries defining each variable in the clinical and demographic datasets
- Protocols used for MRI data acquisition, including parameters for structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS scans
- README files providing an overview of the dataset structure, contents, and any specific instructions for use
- Study instruments and questionnaires used to collect clinical and demographic data

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools and software will be needed to access or manipulate the shared scientific data, particularly for analyzing MRI imaging data. Required tools may include:
- FMRIB Software Library (FSL) for MRI data analysis
- Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM) software for fMRI data analysis
- Magnetic Resonance User Interface (MRUI) for 1H fMRS data analysis
These tools can be accessed through their respective websites or academic licenses.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. The project will adhere to the following standards:
- Neuroimaging Informatics Technology Initiative (NIfTI) for MRI data
- Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) for organizing and describing MRI data
- Standardized vocabularies and ontologies for clinical and demographic data, such as those provided by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) or the World Health Organization (WHO)
These standards will be applied during data collection, processing, and sharing to ensure consistency and compatibility with other datasets.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the National Institute of Mental Health Data Archive (NDA). The NDA provides a secure, centralized repository for human subjects data and associated metadata, facilitating data sharing and collaboration among researchers.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: Scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the use of persistent unique identifiers. Each participant's data will be associated with a global unique identifier (GUID) generated according to NDA guidelines, ensuring that data can be linked across different datasets while maintaining participant confidentiality.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. Data will be available for a minimum of 10 years following the end of the project to allow for extended research and analysis opportunities.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse include informed consent limitations and privacy and confidentiality protections. All participants will provide broad consent for data sharing, but certain sensitive information may be protected or de-identified to prevent re-identification.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will be controlled through the NDA's data access framework. Researchers will need to register with the NDA and agree to terms of use before accessing the dataset.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer: To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants, all data will be de-identified prior to sharing. De-identification will involve removing direct identifiers (e.g., names, addresses) and applying statistical methods to reduce re-identification risks. Certificates of Confidentiality will also be obtained to further safeguard sensitive information.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the project's Principal Investigator (PI), in collaboration with the institution's research administration office. The PI will ensure that all data management and sharing activities are conducted according to the plan, including data collection, storage, sharing, and protection of human subjects' privacy. Oversight will occur on a quarterly basis during the project period, with annual reports submitted to the NIH detailing progress and any challenges encountered in implementing the plan.
